commitResults.messageTitle: Changed logo and file names from Duke.java to Mochi.java
Added new Task class to replace primitive
Added unmark and mark feature and [ ] indicators in list feature
Added additional captions for list and adding tasks
Added text-ui-test and fixed trailing spaces bug
Added more complex exception handling features
Update code to follow git and java standard
commitResults.messageBody:
Move Task and its subclasses (Todo, Deadline, Event) into the mochi.task
package to separate domain logic from the main CLI.

Update package declarations and import statements across the project to
match the new structure and follow Java naming conventions.

Standardize file headers and add missing Javadoc comments for classes
and key methods to align with the coding standards.

commitResults.messageTitle: Add hard code data in ip/data/mochi.txt
Enable loading saved tasks on startup
commitResults.messageBody:
Add hardcoded data path constants and load tasks from data/mochi.txt
when the chatbot starts, so previously saved tasks appear in the list
immediately on launch.

Parse each line using a pipe-delimited format and reconstruct the
corresponding Task subtype (Todo/Deadline/Event), restoring completion
status as well.

Handle the first-run case where the data file or folder is missing by
continuing with an empty task list instead of crashing.

commitResults.messageTitle: Update javadoc comments and git standard

commitResults.messageBody:
Implement Level 7 save/load support for Mochi by persisting the task
list to a hard disk file and restoring it on startup.

Tasks are now serialized in a pipe-delimited format and written to a
relative, OS-independent path under the data directory. The app also
handles first-run cases where the data folder or save file does not
exist yet by creating the required folder and continuing safely.

Basic corruption tolerance is added by skipping malformed lines during
load and proceeding with the remaining valid tasks.# Please enter a commit message to explain why this merge is necessary,

commitResults.messageTitle: Change Deadline and Event to follow time
Add JavaDoc and Git standard comments

commitResults.messageBody:
Add Level 8 support for dates and times in tasks.

Deadlines now store the /by field as a LocalDate parsed from yyyy-MM-dd.
Events now store /from and /to as LocalDateTime parsed from yyyy-MM-dd HHmm
and are printed in a user-friendly format.

Save/load logic was updated to persist dates in a consistent format and to
reject corrupted lines. Event records are validated so that /to must be
strictly after /from.

commitResults.messageTitle: Implement Storage class and TaskList class
Add JavaDoc and Git standard comments
Update all to follow javadoc and git standard
Refactor app to use Ui, Parser, Storage, and TaskList classes
commitResults.messageBody:
The main class handles UI printing, command parsing, task mutations, and file
persistence in one place.

This makes the code harder to read, test, and extend because unrelated concerns
are tightly coupled and changes in one area easily affect others.

Let's extract the core components into separate classes:
- Ui: handle user interaction (input/output, separators, common messages)
- Parser: convert raw user input into a structured ParsedCommand
- TaskList: encapsulate task collection operations (add/get/remove/size)
- Storage: load tasks from disk and save tasks back to disk

This separation reduces duplication, clarifies responsibilities, and keeps the
main workflow focused on orchestration (parse → execute → save), making future
features (e.g., new commands) easier to add safely.

Add Gradle build support to automate common project tasks.

- Merge upstream Gradle setup from the provided add-gradle-support branch
- Enable building and running Mochi via Gradle tasks
- Prepare project structure for future Gradle-based testing (JUnit)

commitResults.messageTitle: Add JUnit tests for Parser and TaskList
commitResults.messageBody:
Add a basic JUnit test suite to validate core command parsing and task-list
operations.

These tests help catch common edge cases (invalid formats, bad indices) early,
and provide confidence when refactoring for more OOP.

Tests added:
	•	ParserTest: verify parsing for todo/deadline/event and index commands
(mark/unmark/delete), including invalid inputs and date/time formats
	•	TaskListTest: verify add/get/remove and mark/unmark behavior, including
invalid index handling

commitResults.messageTitle: Add declaration of proper coding standard

commitResults.messageBody:
Implemented Level 9 "find" feature to let users search tasks by a
keyword in the description.

Updated the parser to recognize `find <keyword>` and validate that the
keyword is present. Added handling in the main loop to filter tasks and
print only matching items with 1-based indexing.

Extended TaskList with a helper to return matching tasks without
mutating the original list, and added UI output for the "Here are the
matching tasks in your list:" message, matching the required format.

This merges the checkstyle configuration setup into the project.

It adds a shared checkstyle configuration and integrates it with the build
so style violations can be detected consistently.

This helps keep formatting and indentation consistent across main and
test source files.

Add JavaFX GUI entry point and wire Mochi logic to GUI controller.

Extract UI-dependent behavior into Ui and keep Mochi as UI-agnostic
logic via getResponse(String), so the same core can support both
CLI-style commands and GUI interactions.

Introduce JavaFX classes (Launcher, Main, MainWindow, DialogBox) and
FXML layouts to display user and Mochi dialogs in a scrollable view.
Bind scroll position to dialogContainer height so new messages stay
visible without manual scrolling.

Update project configuration to support running the app as a GUI while
preserving existing task parsing, storage format, and task classes.

commitResults.messageTitle: Add help feature and bug fixes
Better GUI: highlight error replies Add a dedicated error dialog style so invalid commands are displayed with a distinct background and text color instead of looking like a normal bot reply.
commitResults.messageBody:
Update the main window input handler to detect error responses and
render them using the new error dialog factory method.

This improves visibility of mistakes and makes the GUI easier to use
when users enter a wrong command.# Please enter a commit message to explain why this merge is necessary,
especially if it merges an updated upstream into a topic branch.

This change gives Mochi a consistent personality across the whole app.

Updated the bot name and response phrases so replies feel more
characterful and less generic across commands and errors.

Refreshed the GUI styling to match the new personality by tweaking
colors, font choices, and icons so the look and tone stay consistent.

commitResults.messageTitle: Add assertions to document key assumptions
commitResults.messageBody:
Add Java assert statements at key points in the code to document
assumptions that should always hold during execution.

Assertions were added around core command handling and task operations
to guard invariants such as non-null parsed commands, valid indices for
index-based commands, and presence of required fields for add/find
commands.

This improves code readability by making expectations explicit, and it
helps catch logic errors early when assertions are enabled during
development.

commitResults.messageTitle: Refactor code to improve readability and structure
commitResults.messageBody:
I refactored several parts of the codebase to make the logic easier to
read and maintain, while keeping the app behavior the same.

I extracted repeated or deeply nested logic into smaller helper methods,
so the main methods are shorter and show the intent more clearly.

I also cleaned up naming and organization where it felt confusing, and
aligned formatting/indentation to match the coding standard more
closely, so checkstyle is easier to satisfy and the code is more
consistent overall.
branch-A-Assertions PR merge
branch-A-CodeQuality PR

commitResults.messageTitle: Add sort command for clearer task overview
commitResults.messageBody:
Before this change, list showed tasks in the order they were added.
As the list grew, it became harder to quickly tell what was coming up
next, especially for deadlines and events.

This commit introduces a new sort command that groups tasks by type
and organizes them in a more useful order. It puts unfinished items
first, then finished ones below, so the user can focus on what still
matters while keeping completed tasks visible for reference.

The goal is to make the app feel more helpful without changing the
existing task creation or storage behavior.

commitResults.messageTitle: Add sort command for a more readable task list
commitResults.messageBody:
This introduces a new sort command that shows tasks in a clearer
order, grouped by task type and completion status.

Deadlines and events are shown with unfinished items first (ordered by
the nearest upcoming time/date), followed by completed/past items.
Todos are grouped separately and sorted alphabetically.

This makes it easier to quickly see what is urgent and what can be
ignored for now, without changing how tasks are stored or entered.

commitResults.messageTitle: Change chatbot and user picture circular
Add pink background to chat window
Change font style and welcome msg
Switch input to TextArea with wrap and stable auto-scroll Updated the GUI input box from a single-line TextField to a TextArea so long user inputs can wrap instead of running off-screen.
commitResults.messageBody:
Added key handling so Enter submits the message while Shift+Enter inserts a newline, keeping typing convenient without losing multiline support.

Fixed the screen “jitter” when typing multiple lines by removing the ScrollPane vvalue binding to dialogContainer height, and switching to an explicit scroll-to-bottom only after new messages are appended.

Also tuned the input area sizing/styling so it stays compact (similar height to the previous input box) while still supporting wrapped text.

commitResults.messageTitle: Change bg colour to dark grey

commitResults.messageBody:
This merge improves the GUI experience without changing Mochi’s core logic.

The input box now supports multi-line text with wrapping, using Enter to send and Shift+Enter to insert a newline.

Chat bubbles wrap more cleanly when the window is resized, and the view scrolls to the latest message automatically.

The overall UI styling was also updated to a dark gray theme with consistent rounded accents for the input area, send button, and message bubbles.

This merge expands the project’s test coverage so most logic that can be reliably tested is now covered by automated JUnit tests. The focus is on core, deterministic behaviour such as parsing, task operations, and storage round-trips, while keeping GUI behaviour out of the automated suite since it is better validated manually.

The new/updated tests aim to catch common regressions early, including invalid command formats, boundary cases for indices, and persistence edge cases like missing or corrupted save data. This makes the codebase safer to refactor and reduces the chance of silent breakage when adding new features.

Manual checks were also carried out for the GUI to confirm the application remains usable across typical variations such as different window sizes and environment settings, since those aspects are not stable enough for unit tests.
